flash.tools.debugger.expression

Interface Context

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ExpressionContext

    public interface Context
    An object which returns a value given a name and appropriate context information.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void assign(Object o, Value v)
      Assign the object o, the value v.
      Context createContext(Object o)

      int getIsolateId()
      The worker id to which this context object belongs.
      Session getSession()
      Returns the session associated with this context, or null.

    • Method Detail

      • lookup

        Object lookup(Object o)
              throws NoSuchVariableException,
                     PlayerFaultException
        Looks for an object of the given name in this context -- for example, a member variable. The returned Object can be of any type at all. For example, it could be:
        • a flash.tools.debugger.Variable
        • your own wrapper around Variable
        • a flash.tools.debugger.Value
        • any built-in Java primitive such as Long, Integer, Double, Boolean, or String
        • any other type you want which has a good toString(); see below
        Since the return type is just Object, the returned value is only meaningful when passed to other functions this interface. For example, the returned Object can be passed to createContext(), assign(), or toValue().
        Parameters:
        o - the object to look up; most commonly a string representing the name of a member variable.
        Throws:
        NoSuchVariableException
        PlayerFaultException

      • lookupMembers

        Object lookupMembers(Object o)
                     throws NoSuchVariableException
        Looks for the members of an object.
        Parameters:
        o - A variable whose members we want to look up
        Returns:
        Some object which represents the members; could even be just a string. See lookup() for more information about the returned type.
        Throws:
        NoSuchVariableException
        See Also:
        lookup(Object)

      • createContext

        Context createContext(Object o)
        Creates a new context object by combining the current one and o. For example, if the user typed "myVariable.myMember", then this function will get called with o equal to the object which represents "myVariable". This function should return a new context which, when called with lookup("myMember"), will return an object for that member.
        Parameters:
        o - any object which may have been returned by this class's lookup() function

      • assign

        void assign(Object o,
          Value v)
            throws NoSuchVariableException,
                   PlayerFaultException
        Assign the object o, the value v.
        Parameters:
        o - a variable to assign to -- this should be some value returned by an earlier call to lookup().
        v - a value, such as a Boolean, Long, String, etc.
        Throws:
        NoSuchVariableException
        PlayerFaultException

      • createPseudoVariables

        void createPseudoVariables(boolean oui)
        Enables/disables the creation of variables during lookup calls. This is ONLY used by AssignmentExp for creating a assigning a value to a property which currently does not exist.

      • toValue

        Value toValue(Object o)
        Converts the object to a Value.
        Parameters:
        o - Either object that was returned by an earlier call to lookup(), or one of the raw types that can be returned by Value.getValueAsObject().
        Returns:
        the corresponding Value, or null.
        See Also:
        Value.getValueAsObject()

      • toValue

        Value toValue()
        Converts the context to a Value. Very similar to toValue(Object o), except that the object being converted is the object that was used to initialize this context.
        Returns:
        the corresponding Value, or null.

      • getSession

        Session getSession()
        Returns the session associated with this context, or null. This can legitimately be null; for example, in fdb, you are allowed to do things like "set $columnwidth = 120" before beginning a debugging session.

      • getIsolateId

        int getIsolateId()
        The worker id to which this context object belongs.
